content: The Act is titled the "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" and aims to strengthen state laws regarding tobacco product sales to individuals under the age of 18. The Act "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" requires states to have laws prohibiting the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18 years old, and possession of tobacco products by minors in public places. The Act "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" mandates states to prohibit the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18 years old and possession of tobacco products by minors in public places. Law enforcement must notify parents if a minor is caught purchasing or possessing tobacco. Retailers must notify employees about state laws prohibiting the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18 years old. They must also inform parents or guardians if a minor is caught purchasing or possessing tobacco products in public places. State law prohibits the sale or distribution of tobacco products to individuals under 18 years of age. Employers can avoid violation by verifying age or implementing a compliance program. Violators may face civil liability. The law prohibits selling tobacco to individuals under 18. Employers must verify age or have a compliance program. Violators may face penalties and community service. Some states have delayed enforcement until fiscal year 2012. In fiscal year 2010, states must comply with grant conditions under section 1921. Starting from the first applicable fiscal year, states must set goals to reduce retailer violations of tobacco laws through inspections. The violation rate should not exceed 20% in 2010, 19% in 2011, and 18% in 2012. In subsection (a), inspections must be conducted annually to monitor violations of tobacco laws. The violation rate should decrease each fiscal year, starting at 20% in 2010 and reaching 10% in 2020 and beyond. Enforcement measures are outlined in subsection (c). Enforcement of tobacco laws requires annual inspections to reduce violations, with violation rates decreasing annually from 20% in 2010 to 10% in 2020 and beyond. States must enforce laws to restrict tobacco access to individuals under 18 years of age through random inspections for compliance. States receiving funding for tobacco law enforcement must conduct annual random inspections to ensure compliance with laws restricting access to individuals under 18 years of age. Additionally, they must submit reports to the Secretary detailing enforcement activities and success in meeting goals. States receiving funding for tobacco law enforcement must conduct annual random inspections to ensure compliance with laws restricting access to individuals under 18 years of age. The State seeking the grant must demonstrate their success in meeting goals and reducing availability of tobacco products to minors, as well as outline strategies for enforcing the law in the upcoming fiscal year. Additionally, funding agreements allow States to use individuals under 18 for compliance testing under specific conditions. The funding agreement for a grant under section 1921 allows States to use individuals under 18 for compliance testing under specific conditions, including written consent from a parent or legal guardian and direct supervision during random inspections. States must also certify their use of State settlement proceeds for the previous calendar year when applying for the grant. The State must certify the use of settlement proceeds for health programs, tobacco control, or economic development to qualify for a grant under section 1921. The Secretary determines State compliance before granting funds. Before granting funds under section 1921, the Secretary determines if a State has complied with specified requirements. Noncompliance may result in a reduction of the grant amount by 10 percent for fiscal year 2010. If the Secretary determines that a State is not in compliance with certain requirements, the allotment under section 1921 for the State may be reduced by 10%, 20%, or 30% for fiscal years 2010, 2011, and 2012 respectively. Beginning in fiscal year 2013, the Secretary may reduce the allotment under section 1921 for a State by 40% if the State is found to be non-compliant with certain requirements. In case of non-compliance with certain requirements, the Secretary may reduce the State's allotment by 10% in addition to any other reductions. The Secretary will also provide assistance in developing and implementing State laws. The Secretary will assist States in establishing and implementing State laws by developing model legislative language and providing technical assistance. The term 'first applicable fiscal year' is defined, and the effective date for the amendment is specified. The term "first applicable fiscal year" is defined as fiscal year 2012 for certain states and fiscal year 2010 for others. The effective date for the amendment is specified to apply to the first applicable fiscal year and subsequent years. SEC. 3. PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF INGREDIENTS. The Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act is amended to make ingredient information accessible to the public online within 48 hours of submission to the Secretary.
